	Emergency Response Program
	
	The facility will conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate any emergency response actions necessary with the Martin County Local Emergency Planning Committee.  Also involved in emergency response for the facility will be the Martin County Sheriff Department and the Martin County Volunteer Fire Department.  The Plant Supervisor is responsible for coordinating the emergency actions when an incident occurs within the facility.  An emergency response program is in place at the facility, which has been coordinated with local officials.  The Red Lake Gas Plant is designated as a non-responding stationary source. The emergency planning and response program provides the essential information for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.
	

	Continuous Safety Improvement Efforts 
	
	WTGs Environmental, Health, and Safety Management System, forms the framework for continuous process safety improvement.  Some of the key components are:
	
-	Incorporating Change Management provisions ensure that the potential safety and health impacts of any change made to process chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures are considered.
-	The Hazard Assessment provisions serve as a tool to ensure timely evaluation of potential process hazards and verification of safeguards, thereby leading to continual improvements in process safety and safe work practices.
-	The Preventative Maintenance program ensures that process equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs in place at the facility are part of the high standards striven for by WTG.  These high standards include:

-	Operating in compliance with required environmental permits and regulations. 
-	Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that unintentional releases are minimized.
-	Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that the small releases associated with normal operation and maintenance will be minimized to the extent possible.
-	Correcting non-compliance found by regular audits of the facility.


Prevention Program

The Red Lake Gas Plant is operating under a prevention program that involves identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases.  A few examples of the prevention features implemented at this program 1 facility include:

-	Providing overpressure relief valves on pressurized vessels.
-	Providing level transmitters and alarms on vessels to help prevent overfilling.
-	Minimizing the possibility of an interruption in the combustion of hydrocarbon vapors by having a continuous flare.
-	Installing hydrocarbon gas detectors throughout the gas plant.
-	Installing fire eye detectors throughout the gas plant to alarm personnel of a possible fire.
-	Installing security lighting to facilitate observation of the entire facility.
-	Minimizing the possibility of emergencies by manning the facility 24/7/365.
-	Providing an evacuation alarm system in order to safely evacuate the facility during an emergency.
-	Conducting periodic operational rounds to ensure problems are detected and corrected in a timely manner.

Hydrocarbon liquids from the slug catcher and the three-phase separator are routed to a stabilizer.  In the stabilizer, water, light-end vapors, and other impurities are removed. Condensate and wastewater (slop) from the various process separators, dehydration unit, cryogenic unit, and scrubbers are routed to storage tanks. There are no toxic substances present at the facility in amounts greater than threshold quantity.  Hydrogen sulfide, the only RMP toxic substance found in the process, is stored in quantities far below the RMP threshold quantity.

Introduction and Policies

WTG North Permian Midstream LLC (WTG) is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors and the public while complying with applicable laws and regulations.  WTGs management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of the Environmental, Health, and Safety Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators.

The purpose of this Risk Management Plan (RMP) is to provide information about operations at the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency planning and response plans in the event of an accidental release, the five-year accident history of the facility, and continuous improvement efforts to improve safety at the facility.  

This submission is being sent to EPA as required by 40 CFR 68.190 (b) (5), which requires an RMP update due to a revised hazard review. The revised hazard review incorporates Train 2 into the Train 1 hazard review.    


Non-Responding Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

WTG owns and operates a natural gas processing plant located near Stanton, Texas.  The Red Lake Gas Plant (RLGP) treats and dehydrates natural gas to produce residue gas (methane) and natural gas liquids (NGL).  After processing, the residue gas and NGL exit the plant via product pipelines.

The incoming raw field gas/hydrocarbon liquids mixture enters the facility and flows into a slug catcher.  Gas exits the slug catcher and is routed to a three-phase separator.  The gas is then treated to remove hydrogen sulfide (H2S), carbon dioxide (CO2), water, and excess nitrogen before being sent to the cryogenic processing unit.
